repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: vim.tbl_filter iterates over both the dict and list parts of the table, but always returns a pure list table.
fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13806

Additionally, the vim.tbl_ and vim.list_ functions are largely set to be deprecated.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24572

Solution: Add vim.list.filter() to focus specifically on the list part of a table.

The dict portion of the table can be addressed in a separate PR.

-----------------

~~One question - How do you run the tests with Lua 5.1? I want to verify that the nil handling is correct there.~~

comment_data.body:
I'd tend to change this to return a new list instead of mutating the argument. More in line with other languages/stdlib functions that filter lists - so probably less confusing.

Also easier to reason about correctness and the type signature already implies it given it returns a result.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1818,6 +1818,36 @@ vim.list.bisect({t}, {val}, {opts})                        *vim.list.bisect()*
         (`integer`) index serves as either the lower bound or the upper bound
         position.
 
+vim.list.filter({t}, {f})                                  *vim.list.filter()*
+    Filter a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Applies function `f` to all values in table `t`. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.

comment_data.body:
That would make the behavior of `vim.list.unique()` and `vim.list.filter()` differ. I take it you'd want to make that change to `vim.list.unique()` as well? I have found it a bit strange that `vim.list.unique()` mutates its list.

Alternatively, if the mutating behavior is kept, perhaps it might be worth removing the return so it's more obvious from the signature that it mutates.

         (`integer`) index serves as either the lower bound or the upper bound

+    Filter a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Applies function `f` to all values in table `t`. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.

comment_data.body:
Judging from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35067 there wasn't much discussion about returning a new list vs. mutating.

> Alternatively, if the mutating behavior is kept, perhaps it might be worth removing the return so it's more obvious from the signature that it mutates.

I'd agree, but also: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35067#discussion_r2231315371

cc @lewis6991
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1818,6 +1818,36 @@ vim.list.bisect({t}, {val}, {opts})                        *vim.list.bisect()*
         (`integer`) index serves as either the lower bound or the upper bound
         position.
 
+vim.list.filter({t}, {f})                                  *vim.list.filter()*
+    Filter a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Applies function `f` to all values in table `t`. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.

comment_data.body:
Mutating by default seems like the right choice because callers can opt-in to immutability via `deepcopy()`, whereas opt-out requires a parameter (on every `vim.list.*` function...). Right?

> Alternatively, if the mutating behavior is kept, perhaps it might be worth removing the return so it's more obvious from the signature that it mutates.


Returning the result improves ergonomics:

```lua
-- with return
x = vim.list.foo(vim.deepcopy(...))

-- without return
x = vim.deepcopy(...)
vim.list.foo(x)
```

The performance tradeoff is that `vim.deepcopy()` does an extra scan. But if that matters, then `vim.iter` should be used?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1818,6 +1818,36 @@ vim.list.bisect({t}, {val}, {opts})                        *vim.list.bisect()*
         (`integer`) index serves as either the lower bound or the upper bound
         position.
 
+vim.list.filter({t}, {f})                                  *vim.list.filter()*
+    Filter a list-like table in-place.
+
+    Applies function `f` to all values in table `t`. The operation is
+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.

@@ -535,6 +535,53 @@ function vim.list.bisect(t, val, opts)
   end
 end
 
+--- Filter a list-like table in-place.
+---
+--- Applies function `f` to all values in table `t`. The operation is performed in-place and the
+--- input table is modified.
+---
+--- Example:
+--- ```lua
+--- local t = { 1, 2, 3, 4 }
+--- vim.list.filter(t, function(x)
+---   return x <= 2
+--- end)
+--- -- t is now { 1, 2 }
+---
+--- local t = { { id = 1 }, { id = 2 }, { id = 3 } }
+--- vim.list.filter(t, function(x)
+---   return x.id == 2
+--- end)
+--- -- t is now { { id = 2 } }
+--- ```
+---
+--- @generic T
+--- @param t T[] A comparable list.
+--- @param f fun(x: T): boolean The filter predicate
+--- @return T[] : The filtered list
+--- @see |Iter:filter()|
+function vim.list.filter(t, f)

comment_data.body:
show an example with assignment + immutability
```suggestion
--- -- Use deepcopy() to avoid mutating the list.
--- local filtered = vim.list.filter(vim.deepcopy(t), function(x)
---   return x.id == 2
--- end)
```

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Filters a |lua-list| in-place, excluding items for which `fn(item)` returns false or nil.
```

   end

+--- Filter a list-like table in-place.

@@ -62,4 +62,67 @@ describe('vim.list', function()
     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, target, { bound = 'upper' }), index(target) + 1)
     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, num + 1, { bound = 'upper' }), index(num) + 1)
   end)
+
+  it('vim.list.filter()', function()
+    local list_filter = vim.list.filter

comment_data.body:
Deepcopy would be too much for most cases - a shallow copy would be sufficient.
The point about the mutating version being composable is fair, but makes it slightly less ergonomic and more importantly, I suspect it's easy to get wrong given that you typically need more context to judge if its use is safe - and filter functions in other languages do tend to return copies. E.g.:

- [python filter](https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#filter)
- [js filter](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter)
- [java filter](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/stream/Stream.html#filter-java.util.function.Predicate-) (although this is closer to vim.iter.filter)
- [rust filter](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.filter)

(I actually can't think of any that have a mutating version in their stdlib?)
(My intuition would also be to look for something like a `vim.list.remove(xs, fn)` if wanting to remove entries from a list matching a predicate)


That said - these are maybe all also closer to `vim.iter(..):filter()` - which raises the question if we even need a `vim.list.filter()`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1818,6 +1818,36 @@ vim.list.bisect({t}, {val}, {opts})                        *vim.list.bisect()*
         (`integer`) index serves as either the lower bound or the upper bound

+    Filter a list-like table in-place.

+    performed in-place and the input table is modified.

comment_data.body:
? This does not meet the definition of `:help lua-list` . If this is just for test coverage, that's fine. But I would not expect `vim.list` to have defined behavior for "sparse" arrays. In fact, I would expect all `vim.list` functions to throw an error if `nil` is encountered before the end of the list? cc @neovim/core 

If `vim.list` behaves differently for jit/non-jit that seems like a big problem.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -62,4 +62,65 @@ describe('vim.list', function()
     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, target, { bound = 'upper' }), index(target) + 1)
     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, num + 1, { bound = 'upper' }), index(num) + 1)
   end)
+
+  it('vim.list.filter()', function()
+    eq(
+      { 1, 2, 2, 1 },
+      vim.list.filter({ 4, 1, 3, 2, 2, 3, 1, 4 }, function(x)
+        return x <= 2
+      end)
+    )
+
+    eq(
+      { 1, 2, 3, 4 },
+      vim.list.filter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }, function()
+        return true
+      end)
+    )
+
+    eq(
+      {},
+      vim.list.filter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }, function()
+        return false
+      end)
+    )
+
+    local string_sub = string.sub
+    eq(
+      { 'bar', 'baz' },
+      vim.list.filter({ 'foo', 'bar', 'baz' }, function(x)
+        local first = string_sub(x, 1, 1)
+        return first == 'b'
+      end)
+    )
+
+    eq(
+      { { id = 1 }, { id = 2 } },
+      vim.list.filter({ { id = 1 }, { id = 2 }, { id = 3 } }, function(x)
+        return x.id <= 2
+      end)
+    )
+
+    eq(
+      { 1, 2, field = 1 },
+      vim.list.filter({ 1, 2, 3, 4, field = 1 }, function(x)
+        return x <= 2
+      end)
+    )
+
+    local r = vim.list.filter({ 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, nil, 6, 6, 7, 7 }, function(x)
+      -- Because PUC Lua treats the nil as part of the list table
+      if x == nil then

comment_data.body:
In LuaJIT, it never touches the sparse part of the table and behaves as the lua-list doc describes.

But in 5.1, `#r` returns 12 and it iterates through the whole thing. Without the explicit nil check in the test, it does indeed throw an error.

I agree that it should not be defined behavior. I had adapted the test from list.unique for coverage purposes and figured it was best left at that.

@@ -62,4 +62,65 @@ describe('vim.list', function()
     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, target, { bound = 'upper' }), index(target) + 1)

     eq(vim.list.bisect(list, target, { bound = 'upper' }), index(target) + 1)

comment_regular_data.body: Add `--- @see |Iter:filter()|` (and the reciprocal `--- @see |vim.list.filter()|` to `Iter:filter()`) so it matches the pairs of `Iter:unique()` and `vim.list.unique()`.

> How do you run the tests with Lua 5.1?

to build with "PUC Lua" instead of LuaJit:

    make CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS="-DPREFER_LUA=ON" DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS="-DUSE_BUNDLED_LUAJIT=OFF -DUSE_BUNDLED_LUA=ON"

> Add `--- @see |Iter:filter()|` (and the reciprocal `--- @see |vim.list.filter()|` to `Iter:filter()`) so it matches the pairs of `Iter:unique()` and `vim.list.unique()`.

Done

> > How do you run the tests with Lua 5.1?
> 
> to build with "PUC Lua" instead of LuaJit:
> 
> ```
> make CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS="-DPREFER_LUA=ON" DEPS_CMAKE_FLAGS="-DUSE_BUNDLED_LUAJIT=OFF -DUSE_BUNDLED_LUA=ON"
> ```

Thank you. I corrected the failing PUC Lua test. It ran successfully locally.

Ran into a use case where I needed to add items to a list, filter them, add more items to a list, then only filter the new items.

To address, I added an opts table that lets you set the starting index to filter from.

> Ran into a use case where I needed to add items to a list, filter them, add more items to a list, then only filter the new items.

What prevents you from filtering the new items as they are added? I'm a big unsure if this needs to be a part of `vim.list.filter()` (although I suppose it doesn't hurt).

> > Ran into a use case where I needed to add items to a list, filter them, add more items to a list, then only filter the new items.
> 
> What prevents you from filtering the new items as they are added? I'm a big unsure if this needs to be a part of `vim.list.filter()` (although I suppose it doesn't hurt).

In my particular case, nested function calls where too many params are already being passed. Admittedly might be something I could weed out with further refinement.

Not married to this if it makes the function too bulky.

The `start` option feels unrelated to the purpose of `vim.list.filter()`. imo it should be removed, but I could definitely be convinced otherwise. If it's kept, the option should probably also be added to `vim.list.unique()` for api consistency.
If you do keep it, rename `start` to `lo`, and add a `hi` argument, so it matches the options for `vim.list.bisect()`. Although I still think it should be dropped.

I ended up letting it go. I liked your ideas for thinking more broadly about how the interfaces with the lists could work. But it started seeming to me like it was creating feature confusion with vim.iter, rather than letting vim.list stay light weight.

Given https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/37821#discussion_r2809032389 and #13806 , let's be clear about the actual problem we are solving here. The current PR description doesn't really clarify that.

Based on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13806#issuecomment-3694950788 it sounds like `tbl_filter` is actually just broken, but we're afraid to fix it, and instead want to deprecate it while adding this new "correct" form.

Is that a correct description?

Also, why isn't `vim.iter:filter()` acceptable?

> Based on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13806#issuecomment-3694950788 it sounds like tbl_filter is actually just broken, but we're afraid to fix it

I haven't seen a concrete use case yet that would be broken by a fix? My gut feeling is that this would be a very small number, so I'd rather make them (helped with an equivalent `vim.iter.filter` snippet in the documentation) not rely on broken behavior rather than to force everyone else to adapt to a single-function deprecation.

(The question of replacing `vim.tbl_foo` with a proper _and consistent_ `vim.list`/`vim.table` API is orthogonal to this and should be handled separately, holistically (i.e., with a worked-out migration plan) and on its own merit.)

> > Based on [#13806 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13806#issuecomment-3694950788) it sounds like tbl_filter is actually just broken, but we're afraid to fix it
> 
> I haven't seen a concrete use case yet that would be broken by a fix? My gut feeling is that this would be a very small number, so I'd rather make them (helped with an equivalent `vim.iter.filter` snippet in the documentation) not rely on broken behavior rather than to force everyone else to adapt to a single-function deprecation.

Given that tbl_filter seems to be used in practice mostly for list iteration, you could make it iterate over ipairs() instead of pairs(). Though that does make the naming awkward.

> 
> (The question of replacing `vim.tbl_foo` with a proper _and consistent_ `vim.list`/`vim.table` API is orthogonal to this and should be handled separately, holistically (i.e., with a worked-out migration plan) and on its own merit.)

I don't have a problem with this. I figured list.filter() specifically was worth doing because of the tbl_filter issue, but having another deprecation is an obvious pain point.

> Also, why isn't `vim.iter:filter()` acceptable?

For a hot path or a really simple snippet of code, I'd rather have something like this than standing up an iterator.

But if there are concerns about this breaking the overall picture of table handling, I wouldn't call it an urgent enough use case to run up against that.

Sounds like the first few steps are:
- Fix `vim.tbl_filter()`.
- Potentially make `vim.list.unique()` not mutate its argument to bring it in line with what most people would expect.

And then we can decide if `vim.tbl_filter()` should be moved into the `vim.list` namespace or deprecated after that.

Is this a good assessment?

> Potentially make vim.list.unique() not mutate its argument to bring it in line with what most people would expect.

No. The whole reason `unique` was added was to have a function that works on the list in place to minimize allocations.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lua): add vim.list.filter()
